citation.article-title: Azotobacter salinestris sp. nov., a sodium-dependent, microaerophilic, and aeroadaptive nitrogen-fixing bacterium.

p.s: Description of Azotobacter salinestris sp. nov.
Azotobacter salinestris (sal. in. es' tris. N. L. adj. salinus, saline; L. suff. -estris, belonging to, living in; N. L. adj. salinestris, living in saline environments)
The data below are summarized from this study and previous studies (24, 25, 27, 34) which have been conducted with type strain 184.
The type strain does not form appreciable capsule polysaccharide, whereas other isolates may form considerable amounts of capsule.
Gram negative.
Young cells (18 h old) are elongated and oval with pointed ends (2 by 3 to 4 μm) and occur singly, in pairs, or chains of six to eight cells in actively growing cultures.
Motile by means of peritrichous flagella (Fig. 5).
Each flagellar filament has a wavelength of 2.7 to 2.9 μm and an amplitude of 0.36 to 0.55 μm and is 9 to 10 μm long.
Poly-β-hydroxybutyrate is formed.
Older cells are rounder, larger (diameter, 3 to 5 μm), pleomorphic, and nonmotile and form cysts.
Encystment is induced in young cultures by incubation with 0.2% β-hydroxybutyrate as the sole carbon source.
Growth in all media is Na+ dependent.
Optimal growth is promoted by ≥1 mM NaCl.
Cells grow well in the presence of 0.25 mM Na+ and 25 mM Li+ or 25 mM Mg2+; 15 to 25 mM K+ or 15 to 25 mM Rb+ is antagonistic to growth.
Optimal growth requires >5 μM soluble iron.
Colonies develop on solid media after 2 to 3 days of incubation at 30°C.
Cells are killed by 100 μM H2O,.
Colonies are not formed in numbers proportional to the dilution of a culture because of the presence of toxic oxygen products in normal media.
Capsules are absent in the type strain, but may be formed by other isolates.
Colonies are brown to brownish black because of the production of a water-insoluble, cell-associated catechol melanin.
Water-soluble catechol formation precedes melanization.
Melanization is greatest in aerated, nitrogen-free medium and is promoted by trace amounts (0.25 μg/ml) of Cu+ or Cu2+.
Nitrogen fixation is optimal with molybdate, but nitrogen is fixed by molybdate-starved cells in the presence of vanadate.
Nitrogen fixation is optimal at 35°C and minimal at 28°C.
Nitrogen-fixing growth in liquid medium is initially microaerophilic, but the cells can adapt to growth in vigorously aerated medium.
Cells inoculated at a low density into nitrogen-free medium or aerated vigorously before aeroadaptation do not grow.
NO3- is assimilated without NO2- or N2 production.
Urease is produced.
Catalase negative in the H22 spot test.
A single, weakly active catalase electromorph is present, which migrates on nondenaturing polyacrylamide gels with the same relative mobility as beef liver catalase.
Multiple peroxidase electromorphs are present, and a single superoxide dismutase is present.
All of the enzyme activities are dependent on iron.
Optimal growth occurs at pH 7.2 to 7.5, and growth is limited at pH 6.2 and 8.2 (nitrogen fixing) or pH 9.0 (with ammonium acetate).
Acid is produced during aerobic or microaerophilic growth in a sodium-dependent manner.
Higher available NaCl concentrations promote greater acidification of the medium until a growth-inhibiting pH is attained.
The acid released by nitrogen-fixing cultures on agar-solidified medium containing 0.5 to 1.5% (wt/vol) NaCl is sufficient to solubilize CaCO3.
An alkaline reaction is produced in marine broth alone, and an acid reaction is produced in marine broth containing glucose under oxidative or fermentative conditions.
Strains are very susceptible to streptomycin and kanamycin (inhibited by ≤1 μg/ml) and resistant to chloramphenicol (40 μg/ml).

The carbon substrates used for growth are the same as those described previously for Azotobacter chroococcum, including 0.25% sodium benzoate, 0.5 to ≥1.0% fructose, galactose, glucose, mannitol, melibiose, starch, and sucrose.
The substrates not used for growth include 0.5 to ≥1.0% arabinose, cellobiose, glutamate, glycerol, lactose, mannose, rhamnose, and xylose.

Acid is produced during incubation with the growth-promoting substrates fructose, galactose, glucose, mannitol, melibiose, and sucrose and with the non-growth-promoting substrates arabinose, cellobiose, lactose, mannose, rhamnose, and xylose.

Strains have been isolated from slightly saline, neutral to slightly alkaline soils from the Canadian provinces Alberta (type strain 184), Saskatchewan, British Columbia, and the Yukon and from a saline soil from Egypt.
The G+C content is 65.19 to 65.98 mol%.
Strain 184 is the type strain; this strain has been deposited in the American Type Culture Collection, Rockville, Md., as strain ATCC 49674.
